Award.AwardTitle: Nano and Microprinting Equipment for Novel Bioparticle Separations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1159763
P.I.: Adrienne R. Minerick

This NSF award by the Chemical and Biological Separations program supports the acquisition and installation of a BioForce Nano eNablerTM Instrument to facilitate bioparticle and proteomics separation research at Michigan Tech and in the Upper Peninsula region. The microprinting tool will enable work by Professors Adrienne Minerick, Caryn Heldt, David Shonnard, Wan Jin Jahng, and others. Specifically, we will explore high sensitivity, high-resolution electrokinetic protein separations, molecular recognition blood cell separations, optimizing cellulosic enzyme catalysis for separations, and isolating proteomic biomarkers of retinal degenerative disease. The Nano eNablerTM is essential equipment infrastructure for the Biotechnology Research community (BRC) and will be utilized to make innovative contributions to chemical and biological separations. The PI's proposed projects all harness the versatile, femtoliter printing of biological materials to defined locations with nanoscale accuracy offered by the Nano eNablerTM. The potential bioparticle separations applications range from hemoglobin variant diagnosis, exploiting peptides for specialty viral/pathogen capture, optimizing cellulase activity and separations, to proteome isolations and are fully compatible with fluorescence or quantum dot-based indicators. Common advantages with each application include significantly smaller sample consumption, higher sensitivity, lower detection limits, as well as faster and higher separation efficiencies. This shared instrumentation will enable the PI's research to meet the demand in the scientific and industrial communities for smaller scale bioseparations, with concurrent simpler preparation, simpler operation, and versatility.

The Nano eNablerTM will transform research capabilities, enhance research graduate and undergraduate student education and training, and augment course instruction. The PIs have strong mentoring track records and are committed to actively recruiting undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups to participate in research activities. Minerick's surface isoelectric focusing research has the potential to impact protein separations, hemoglobinopathy diagnosis, and thus health care practices on a global scale and contributes to the philosophies of sustainability by decreasing resource utilization for chemical analysis. The PI team has a strong publication record of intellectual contributions in their respective fields and acquisition of this instrument will facilitate innovative and ongoing bioseparations research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the acquisition of a BioForce Nano eNablerTM Instrument capable of printing femtoliter volumes of fluids onto surfaces.  This instrument was installed in the lab at Michigan Technological University within 3 months of receiving the funding.  This was the first instrument of its type at Michigan Tech and in the Upper Peninsula region. It has been utilized, under the supervision of the specially trained graduate student for the PI, co-PI, and has been made available to members of the Biotech Research Center at Michigan Tech.  The microprinting tool has enabled burgeoning research in high-resolution electrokinetic protein separations, molecular recognition blood cell separations, and cellulosic enzyme catalysis separations.   Data collected from this instrument has contributed to two research proposals to NSF (a bioseparations proposal and a biosensor proposal) in addition to providing the main source of data for two manuscripts which should be complete for submission in early Spring.  In addition, the Ph.D. graduate student working with the Nano eNablerTM has submitted his Ph.D. proposal for evaluation by his committee this month.  This major educational milestone contains the data collected by the student with the instrument; the committee's job is to evaluate the quality and the remaining, proposed work for the Ph.D. student to complete his degree.  The instrument has been essential to advance the research capabilities of the PI team and related researchers at Michigan Tech.  The resulting research is novel and will impact knowledge in bioseparations and biosensors.

Modified by: Adrienne R Minerick
